description: Medium - Saguntum and the Invasion Begins

questions.question: What was Saguntum's political status and strategic significance in the region around 220 BCE?
options: A Spanish city that developed commercial ties with Rome and sought Roman military protection
A Carthaginian stronghold that had been under Carthaginian control since initial Spanish conquest
A neutral trading city that maintained equal relations with both Rome and Carthage equally
A Roman province that was directly administered by Roman governors and magistrates
An independent Greek colony that refused to align with either Rome or Carthage politically

questions.question: Why did Hannibal begin military operations against Saguntum starting in 220 BCE?
options: He wanted to demonstrate Carthaginian military superiority to Rome diplomatically
Saguntum possessed valuable silver mines that Carthage needed for economic recovery
He saw Saguntum as an obstacle to complete Carthaginian dominance of Spanish territories
Rome had attacked Saguntum first and Hannibal responded defensively to Roman aggression
Saguntum was harboring Carthaginian rebels who had fled Spain and needed elimination

questions.question: How did Rome respond when Hannibal began the siege of Saguntum militarily?
options: Rome immediately invaded Spain with a massive army force to relieve the besieged city
Rome ignored the situation and focused on defending other Mediterranean territories instead
Rome sent envoys to demand that Hannibal cease operations and withdraw completely
Rome and Carthage negotiated a diplomatic agreement protecting Saguntum from conquest
Rome supplied Saguntum with military forces and supplies to strengthen its defensive position

questions.question: What was the outcome of Saguntum's siege and what did it signify politically?
options: The city surrendered peacefully and was incorporated into Carthaginian Spanish territories
Rome successfully relieved the city and maintained it as a Roman ally militarily intact
The city fell after months of resistance and was destroyed, challenging Rome's authority
The siege was abandoned when Rome threatened to declare war on Carthage immediately
The city was evacuated by Rome and its population relocated to Italian territories safely
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Fall of Saguntum and the Path to War

questions.question: What was the approximate size of Hannibal's invasion army in 218 BCE? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: The army consisted of approximately 90,000 men total from various sources and territories
The force included infantry, cavalry, and war elephants transported from North Africa
The invasion army was relatively small at around 30,000 soldiers due to limited resources
The force was composed entirely of Spanish soldiers without Carthaginian military units
The army represented an enormous force for the era requiring complex logistics and supply
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Army and the March

questions.question: What route did Hannibal choose for his invasion of Italy and what were its characteristics?
options: He sailed directly across the Mediterranean with his army using Carthaginian naval dominance
He marched northward through Spain and Gaul and crossed the Alps into the Italian peninsula
He conquered Mediterranean islands as stepping stones to eventually reach Italian territories
He avoided the Alps entirely and sailed around the Mediterranean coast to southern Italy
He followed coastal roads through Sicily and invaded Italy from the island to the north
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Army and the March

questions.question: What challenges did Hannibal's army face militarily and logistically?  (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: The Alpine passes were treacherous and winter weather caused enormous casualties and losses
Local Alpine peoples actively attacked the army and prevented safe passage through the mountains
The passage was surprisingly easy and Hannibal's army emerged nearly intact into Italy
Thousands of soldiers and many elephants were lost during the difficult mountain crossing operation
Supply lines were completely cut off forcing the army to forage for food continuously
questions.text_reference: Section 5: The Army and the March

questions.question: What was the strategic outcome of the Battle of the Trebia River (218 BCE)?
options: Roman forces defeated Hannibal's army and halted the Carthaginian invasion completely
Hannibal's army defeated Roman forces under consul Scipio and pushed Romans back northward
Both armies withdrew from the region having achieved limited strategic objectives militarily
The battle resulted in mutual agreement to end hostilities and negotiate peace immediately
Roman reinforcements arrived and established clear military dominance in northern Italy

questions.question: How did Hannibal plan to achieve ultimate victory against Rome after initial victories? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: He would win pitched battles to demonstrate Roman military vulnerability and weakness
He would demoralize Rome's Italian allies to encourage them to switch sides eventually
He would immediately attack Rome itself and force the city to surrender militarily
He would accumulate Italian support to provide his army additional forces and resources
He would force Rome to negotiate peace terms favorable to Carthage through military pressure

questions.question: What was Hannibal's assumption about how Italian allies would respond to Carthaginian military victories?
options: Italian cities would remain completely loyal to Rome regardless of military outcomes
Italian cities would form independent alliances to protect themselves from both Rome and Carthage
Italian populations would actively rebel against Rome before Hannibal requested assistance
Italian cities would request military protection from Egypt and other Mediterranean powers
Italian allies would defect to Carthage and provide military support against Rome
